title: 107_hr3922
content: The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" prevents corporate expatriation to avoid US income tax. The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" amends the definition of domestic for corporations and partnerships under the Internal Revenue Code. It states that a corporation or partnership is considered domestic if created or organized in the United States or under U.S. law, unless specified otherwise by the Secretary. In a corporate expatriation transaction, the acquiring corporation is treated as domestic. The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" amends the definition of domestic for corporations and partnerships under the Internal Revenue Code. In a corporate expatriation transaction, a nominally foreign acquiring corporation must acquire substantially all properties of a domestic corporation, with more than 80 percent of the acquiring corporation's stock held by former shareholders of the domestic corporation. In a corporate expatriation transaction, if more than 80 percent of the acquiring corporation's stock is held by former shareholders of the domestic corporation, the lower stock ownership requirement can be 50 percent for a nominally foreign corporation with limited business activities in the foreign country of incorporation. In a corporate expatriation transaction, a nominally foreign corporation acquiring properties indirectly constitutes a corporate expatriation transaction. In a corporate expatriation transaction, a nominally foreign corporation acquires properties constituting a trade or business of a domestic partnership, with more than 80 percent of the acquiring corporation's stock held by former partners of the domestic partnership. In a corporate expatriation transaction, a foreign corporation acquires properties of a domestic partnership, with over 80% of the acquiring corporation's stock held by former partners. Special rules apply to related transactions and ownership determination. "In a corporate expatriation transaction, a foreign corporation acquires properties of a domestic partnership, with over 80% of the acquiring corporation's stock held by former partners. Special rules apply to related transactions and ownership determination. The expanded affiliated group, including the acquiring corporation, is not considered in ownership determination. Definitions for 'nominally foreign corporation' and 'expanded affiliated group' are provided." The term 'expanded affiliated group' refers to an affiliated group without certain restrictions. The Secretary of the Treasury will adjust tax rates to offset revenue changes from the amendment. Estimates will guide rate adjustments for future years. Effective dates are specified for these provisions. The amendment allows the Secretary of the Treasury to adjust tax rates based on revenue estimates. It applies to corporate expatriation transactions after September 11, 2001, and also to transactions before that date for acquiring corporations starting after December 31, 2003.
